newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS - Dlr/yen risk reversals flip for yen puts.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - Dlr/yen risk reversals flip for yen puts.

text.p: Yen puts in dollar/yen options became more expensive than yen calls for the first time since the dollar's uptrend stalled shortly after the Group of Seven (G7) meeting in early February, dealers said.
That, combined with the fact that implied volatilities now tended to rise with the dollar, indicated the market was bracing for a resumption of the dollar's uptrend, they added.

The dollar briefly climbed early in U.S. trading above 124 yen for the first time in three weeks before pulling back on profit-taking, paving the way for a retest of February highs just below 125 yen.

"It seems people are starting to think the dollar's consolidation could be coming to an end and a higher dollar is on the horizon," said Kyoko Hiramatsu, a senior trader at Bank of Yokohama in New York.

Risk reversal, which reflects pricing differential between puts and calls, for one-month 25-delta options stood at 0.1/0.3 percent skewed for yen puts at U.S. midsession against around par late on Thursday.
It had been favoring yen calls for about a month as the dollar topped out after the G7 stated in their communique that the U.S. currency's correction from its 1995 lows was over.
One-month implied volatility pulled back to 9.5/9.7 percent by U.S. midday, in line with spot's retreat, after climbing earlier toward 10 percent. It had ended on Thursday at 9.4/9.7 percent.
"It's come back off a little bit, but there aren't very many people selling," a U.S. bank trader in Chicago said.
Traders said the market had been split for a while on spot's direction as the dollar travelled to and fro between 120 and 125 yen after the G7 meeting.
"As we climbed above 124 yen, the scale tipped toward the bullish side," Hiramatsu at Bank of Yokohama said.
However, traders warned that risk reversals have been a lagging indicator that often betrayed their followers when they flipped.
Still, Hiramatsu said the strength in back-end volatilities was a sign of growing anticipation of a higher dollar. One-year dollar/yen stood at 10.75/10.95 percent, up a quarter point from Thursday.
Traders noted that a recent buildup of knockout options with barrier prices at and slightly beyond 125 yen meant that both spot and volatilities could spike up sharply once the barriers were broken.
Such concerns, combined with caution ahead of the March 25 Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting and the March 31 fiscal year-end for most Japanese corporations underpinned volatilities.
Dollar/mark volatilities were relatively stagnant as the dollar gyrated in familiar territory around 1.70 marks.
One-month dollar/mark was steady to slightly softer at 9.1//9.3 percent. One-year was steady at 9.5/9.7, virtually unchanged.
